· Overall the sales numbers are certainly better than what we thought Kantar and Nielsen data were suggesting, but they are still less good than Morrison’s +0.7% in 1Q. The company maintained its cautious commentary on the market, although it is not new language.

BE

Q1 LfL of -0.8% is better than market share data had suggested and suggests that Sainsbury’s continues to see little impact from recovering competitors. Moreover, we continue to believe that the quality of Sainsbury’s sales growth is markedly higher than that of Morrisons and Tesco, where growth is more promotionally fuelled, and that it suggests a good ongoing customer response to the Value Simplicity programme. With the
shares having been weak of late, reflecting market share data and due to concerns about Asda price cutting, we think they represent good value but retain a Hold rating given our concerns on the potential for weak news flow relating to Argos.

BE

And just briefly, Caz.

11:25 am
BE

Not on the results, but the annual report that came out last Friday.

BE

Caz is the leading Sainsbury bear, and has been for some time.

BE

The main highlight from Sainsbury’s annual report was
the muted implied grocery gross margin investment, still material sales
densities decline and increasing costs, a combination that suggests trends that,
in our view, diminish future years' earnings visibility, particularly in the
context of recent market events (ie Asda’s new focus on volumes over
margins).

11:27 am
BE

 Sales densities: Sales densities ex petrol declined 1.9% YoY in 15/16
following a decline of 3.6% in 14/15.
 Gross margin proxy: The primary gross margin expanded by 43bp on sales
(using cost of inventories as a proxy for COGS). Assuming fuel margins
went up, we estimate that grocery gross margins were at best flat (we
estimate gross margins adjusted for the Bank were down by 20-30bp on an
ex fuel basis last year).
 Costs: Employee costs as a % of sales rose 52bp YoY, rents over sales up
6bp YoY, ‘other costs’ (balancing cost line above EBITDA) as % of sales
up 18bp YoY.
 EBITDAR margin ex fuel: down 37bp YoY to 8.8%. We would have
expected to see a bigger decline given the magnitude of the fall in sales
densities and the rising cost base. We also note that current levels are only
c70bp lower compared to the peak (9.5% in 13/14), while the sales density
continues to decline and the cost base continues to increase.
 Underlying EBIT margin decreased 33bp (known, mainly explained by
the retail business excluding the bank), dragged by the hiking costs and
despite no obvious gross margin investment. For a given Trading Profit
margin, we would have preferred to see some GM investment and better
cost control. But with declining sales densities, this is difficult to achieve.

BE

Etc.

BE

Oh, they also tackle the Asda issue.

11:28 am
BE

Post Cheesewright last week saying Wal-Mart was going to reclaim market share and stop using Asda for cash.

BE

(I'm paraphrasing, but only slightly.)

BE

We believe there was very little of PR in this first public
comment from Walmart International on Asda, particularly after
watching the video online. Mgmt noted a detailed plan in place to
regain share in the UK, with a renewed emphasis on driving volumes
now that the other key markets (e.g. Canada, Mexico) are back on the
right path – this is the first decisive sign of change of focus from
profit to share from Asda and in our view will inevitably imply
further price actions. The incumbents will be forced to react in order
to avoid losing further traffic, we believe, and Sainsbury remains
operationally and financially exposed given its high EBITDAR ex
fuel margins and stretched B/S.

BE

Here's Shore on CMC.

BE

CMC has reported its maiden results as a listed company this morning following its 240p IPO in February. These full year figures to 31st March 2016 show net operating income (revenue) up 18% yoy at £169.4m (Bloomberg consensus £168m) and underlying EBITDA (excluding IPO-related costs) up 16% at £69.2m (Bloomberg consensus £63.3m). This produces underlying PBT up 23% at £62.4m (consensus £56.1m), equivalent to an adjusted earnings per share of 18.0p (consensus 16.5p).

Particularly notable metrics were UK revenue growth of 30% and the 14% increase in total active customers to 57,329, with average revenue per customer up 4% at £2828. The statement notes that there has been ‘a recent easing of trading activity’ but reiterates the growth targets set out at the time of the IPO for £250m of gross revenue by y/e Mar 2020 (£220m of net operating income) remain unchanged. We therefore interpret this as management seeking to reign back any temptation for analysts to push through upgrades on the back of the strong results.

Given broadly similar operational metrics to those reported by IG Group^ (IGG, Sell at 788p), we are intrigued by the current differential in the rating that the market continues to place on the two companies, although some of this has closed more recently as CMC has outperformed. Based on last night’s closing price of 276p, and before any forecast changes flowing from today’s results (likely minor given the comments), CMC trades on 14.9x Mar ’17 consensus eps of 18.5p compared to IG’s current rating of 16.5x our May ’17 eps (47.8p).

11:38 am
PM

But you can have a taste

PM

Our detailed autopsy of Europe’s dire earnings performance of the last 10 years shows that the EPS shortfall has been extremely broad-based, and can't merely be blamed on one or two factors. Our analysis dispels a number of myths that oversimplify the source of Europe’s EPS woes.

PM

Myth #1: Europe’s earning underperformance is all down to Financials and Commodities. Yes, Europe is over-exposed to globally challenged sectors and this has undoubtedly been a headwind, but only a fifth of the ROE gap to the US can be explained by index composition. We calculate that 70% of EPS underperformance vs the US since 2007 has been driven by sectors other than Financials and Commodities.

11:39 am
PM

Myth #2: Europe’s main problem is the lacklustre domestic economy, causing a lack of sales growth. We analysed 8 drivers of EPS to assess the root causes of why the region has undershot the US since 2007. Europe came up short on every count. Despite low EU economic growth, it is striking that relative sales growth was only the 5th biggest contributor to the earnings deficit. Over one-third of the underperformance can be attributed to margins, and almost a quarter to Europe's lack of buybacks.

PM

Myth #3: Margins are low because of a lack of domestic pricing power. Despite a relatively benign cost environment, a lack of pricing power has clearly been a factor for European margins. However, our analysis indicates the margin decline stems more from the EM slowdown than domestic issues, with the unwinding of unsustainably high EM margins a key contributor.

PM

Myth #4: European corporates have plenty of scope to increase buybacks as the ECB starts corporate QE. Many investors hope corporate QE will spur an increase in buybacks, the lack of which has held back EPS growth. However, despite the sharp US releveraging in the last couple of years, the starting position of EU balance sheets means European leverage is actually still higher. The ECB could well spur a rise in buybacks, but it is not obvious that European companies have significant headroom to follow US trends.

11:39 am
PM

BooHoo was mentioned earlier.

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 57.38, up 0.633 (+1.12%), High: 58.00, Low: 56.00, Volume: 6.75m
11:42 am
BE

Beat and raise.

BE

Only question is whether it's already in the price, which is back to pre-profit-warning levels.

BE

I'll let Citi summarise from here, because they still see value.

11:43 am
BE

boohoo has announced a very strong trading statement with overall sales growth of +41%. The UK sales growth of +42% is particularly strong given the recent weakness in apparel sales, again highlighting how the structural shift to online retailing has not decelerated. Based on the strong 1Q trading and the slight raise to guidance (FY17 sales +25-30% from c.+25%), it is likely that consensus forecasts nudge up on the back of this statement.

BE

1Q sales +41% (Citi +30%)

This splits UK +42%, Rest of Europe +40% and Rest of World +37% (Citi +30%, +30%, +30%). In ccy neutral terms growth was +42% for the group with RoE growing at +43% ccy neutral. Overall this compares to growth of +35% in the same period last year and represents a 2-year growth of +75%, ahead of the 2-year growth of +64% reported in 4Q16.

Gross margin 57.6%, -300bps yoy (Citi -350bps)

Gross margin came in at 57.6%, -300bps yoy, driven by planned investments in price and customer proposition.

Guidance raised slightly

boohoo has raised sales guidance to +25-30% yoy, from c.+25%. boohoo expects EBITDA margins to be level yoy.

Implications

FY17e consensus PBT expected to rise marginally — Based on the strong 1Q trading and the slight raise to guidance, it is likely that consensus forecasts nudge up on the back of this statement. For the record, Citi forecast FY17e PBT of £19.5m, (EPS 1.37p, +26.3% yoy), based on sales growth of +25%, GM -170bps and EBIT margins up +10bps yoy.

BE

Growth and profitability justify value

boohoo is a profitable online retailer that generates healthy cashflow. Despite inevitable expansion risks and our preference for aggregation models, we see boohoo as offering long-term structural growth within a clearly-defined market segment where it has significant operational advantages vs peers. Our base case is that margins will be broadly maintained as the company grows. In conjunction with a strong balance sheet, this drives our enthusiasm for the shares.

Buy, target price 65p

Our 65p target price is based on a 10-year DCF. This incorporates a +14% 2017-27e sales CAGR and a terminal EBIT margin of 8%. On 2019e numbers, this equates to a 1.7x EV/Sales multiple and a 31x PE multiple.

11:44 am
BE

David Reynolds at Jefferies also keen.

BE

Our conclusions. A strong beat and raise start to the year thanks to results of prior year
investment. A guide of c.25% revenue growth for FY17 moves up to a range of +25% to
+30%; however, as the company sees this growth come through, it will be plowing it back
into the business, maintaining EBITDA margins around 9.5%-10% over the next few years.

BE

Valuation/Risks
With boohoo showing strong growth all down its P&L, we put it on a peer group P/E and
PEG mean multiples of 41.6x and 1.2x to get to our new PT of 65p, 38.0x 2017 P/E, Buy. Key risk is execution, eCom and technology.

Intermediate Capital Group PLC (ICP:LSE): Last: 645.90, down 20.6 (-3.09%), High: 654.00, Low: 635.50, Volume: 339.27k
BE

Special divi will be nice but it's already in the price, they say.

11:56 am
BE

Operationally, the business is certainly not pausing. In FY16, third-party FUM was +23% YoY to €19.3bn and Fund Management PBT was +18% YoY at £61.2m. We are forecasting a 17% CAGR in Fund Mgt. profits over the next three years. However, we suggest the valuation is close to fully reflecting the special dividend and the near-term potential. Consequently, we move the recommendation from Buy to HOLD.

BE

Good FY16 results

Fund Mgt. PBT of £61.2m was in-line with our forecast and the Investment Company PBT of £97.6m was ahead (Libf: £94m). Gross inflows of €5.2bn were strong (Libf: €4.6bn).

No more special div’s

The £200m special dividend was expected but notification that no further specials are anticipated may mean the stock marks time in the near-term. We don’t rule out more.

Excellent FUM quality

The 3rd-party funds managed by ICP are locked-in for 6-12 years, thus giving excellent earnings visibility. FY17 will be slower for fundraising (Libf: €3.7bn) but still good.

Move to HOLD from Buy

Our TP has reduced slightly, from 703p to 692p. We target 1x NAV and roll forward the Fund Mgt. PE of 15x to CY18. The shares are now close to our fair value, +30% since Feb’16.

BE

Justin Bates the lead analyst there.

11:57 am
undefined
BE

Otherwise in sellside, Citi's had a look at Vedanta and found it to be quite complicated with a lot of debt.

Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 405.00, up 13.4 (+3.42%), High: 405.00, Low: 394.00, Volume: 157.43k
11:58 am
BE

A difficult equity story to sell

Group structure complexity and high leverage still dominate Vedanta's investment case and equally act as deterrents to a number of investors. We see four things that could turn the dial for Vedanta (group structure simplification, deleverage, KCM delivery and integrated aluminium business), but the road to delivery of all of these looks long and bumpy. Following a period of restriction, we resume coverage at Neutral/High Risk with a £4.40 TP.

It can't ever be that simple

A big minority line from Vedanta Ltd will always remain even if the group manages to buy all other minorities. Moreover, investors with a global mandate have an option to avoid the holding company debt/discount and KCM/Zambia risk, meaning that the group risks competing for capital/investors with its own subsidiaries. Moreover, valuation disconnects between the holding and subsidiary companies can increase the vulnerability of the higher-rated name as investors try to tap into arbitrage opportunities.

What changes with Cairn merger?

Due to completion timing uncertainty, dominant minority shareholding and reversal of the bid premium, we don't factor the proposed Cairn India merger into our base case. We estimate a merger on current terms would reduce VED's earnings and NPV by a double-digit % as the gain from higher effective ownership of Cairn India (from 37.7% to 50.1%) would be more than offset by lower effective ownership of all other businesses under VED Ltd as Plc's stake would be diluted to 50.1% (from 62.9% currently) under current merger terms.

Key changes to our model

We update our model for the FY16 results and also incorporate Citi's current commodityand fxestimates. Significantly lower commodity prices since our last publication have resulted in double-digit downgrades to our EPS estimates from FY18 onwards while our FY17 EPS estimate has turned to a negative 52.6c from +48.4c previously due to a lower base. Our NPV has, however, declined only marginally to £16.2/share from £16.7/share due to roll-forward. Our price target (based on NPV and EV/EBITDA valuation methods) declines to £4.40/share from £5.50/share, primarily on significantly lower EBITDA.
